document.masterDocTitle: A revision of the subgenus Bessobates of the genus Netelia from Japan (Hymenoptera, Ichneumonidae, Tryphoninae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A revision of the subgenus Bessobates of the genus Netelia from Japan (Hymenoptera, Ichneumonidae, Tryphoninae)

subSubSection.paragraph: Mesosoma ( Figs 95, 96 ): mesoscutum 1.1–1.3 times as long as wide; scutellum 1.3–1.5 times as long as distance between lateral carinae at its base, lateral carina fading out beyond middle of scutellum; propodeum transstriate on median portion, with sublateral crest absent and represented by swelling.
Fore tibial spur 0.5 times as long as 1 st tarsomere, which is 7.7–9.1 times as long as wide; fore tarsal claw with 12 (♀) and 14–19 (♂) pectines; hind tarsal claw with 10–13 pectines.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 91–96. Males of
Netelia
( Bessobates )
virgata
. 91, 93, Head in dorsal view; 92, 94, head in frontal view; 95, 96, mesosoma in dorsal view; 91, 92, 95, most strongly pigmented male; 93, 94, 96, most weakly pigmented male.

FIGURES 97–98. Wings of male of
Netelia
( Bessobates )
virgata
. 97, Fore wing; 98, hind wing.

subSubSection.paragraph: Head yellow; occiput brownish-yellow to brown; in some specimens, posterior half of interocellar area brown; in some specimens, lower face with a brown spot on median dorsal portion; antenna reddish-yellow. Mesosoma yellow; mesoscutum with blackish-brown stripes on each of median and lateral lobes and a blackish-brown spot behind median stripe, or mesoscutum entirely blackish-brown in some specimens; mesosternum brown to blackishbrown; in some specimens, scutellum, markings on mesopleuron and anterior portion of propodeum brown to blackish-brown. Legs yellow; in some specimens, hind coxa except tip and hind femur except base and tip brown; hind tarsus whitish-yellow. Wings hyaline and tinged with yellow; vein C and pterostigma of fore wing brownishyellow or brown; other veins brown to blackish-brown. Metasoma yellow to blackish-brown; 1 st and 2 nd sterna and 2 nd epipleurum yellow to brownish-yellow.

Distribution. Japan (Hokkaido, Honshu, Shikoku, Kyushu), Palaearctic region, India (?).

Remarks. This species was recorded and its male genitalia were figured from the western Palearctic region (
Delrio, 1975
), Russia (
Tolkanitz, 1974
), Ukraine (Tolkanitz, 1989 ), India (
Kaur and Jonathan, 1979
) and Korea (
Cha and Lee, 1988
). Among these publications, judging from the figures of the paramere, at least the specimens figured by Tolkanitz (1974 , 1989),
Kaur and Jonathan ( 1979 )
and
Cha and Lee ( 1988 )
are thought not to be
virgata
but probably
pallescens
, because their pads are situated equidistant from the dorsal and ventral margins. Thus,
virgata
and its allied species in Russia , India and Korea are in needed of revision.

Although
Tolkanitz ( 1981 a)
synonymized
Paniscus ( Parabates ) virgatus
f.
odaiensis
Uchida, 1934
and
Paniscus ( Parabates ) virgatus
f.
nipponensis
Uchida, 1934
with
virgata
, these synonyms are uncertain because her identification of
virgata
is unreliable. The female holotype of
nipponensis
possesses the blackish brown mesoscutum and mesosternum, the evenly rounded vertex in dorsal view and the relatively long gena (geno-orbital index 2.7 ). Thus,
nipponensis
can be a synonym of
virgata
as treated by
Tolkanitz ( 1981 a)
. However, the female holotype of
odaiensis
possesses the following characters: mesosternum brownish yellow; cu-a of fore wing vertical, nervellar index 0.4 ; propodeum without sublateral crest; length of fore wing 12.6 mm . These characters are shared with
nodai
,
yakushimensis
,
pallescens
and
yamatoensis
, and these species can be distinguished only by characters of the male genitalia. Consequently,
odaiensis
is left as a species incertae sedis.
